h1. Overview {anchor:id=KSuser.Wiki.Wiki_Overview}
This section provides you a guide to use all *Wiki* features and configure the *Wiki* portlet to make it work in your desired way. Before going further, you should know some basic concepts about *Wiki*.
After [accessing the *Wiki* application|#KSuser.access_knowledge], the *Wiki* homepage will appear automatically as below.

!images/wiki_overview.png|align="center"!

*Details*:
||Item|| Description||
|!images/no1.png!|The *Breadcrumb* which shows the page hierarchy.|
|!images/no2.png!|The Wiki administration area which allows administrators only to do space settings. |
|!images/no3.png!|The *Search* box.|
|!images/no4.png!|The pages tree view.|
|!images/no5.png!|The *Page Control* area which helps users take actions with the current page.|
|!images/no6.png!|The defaul content. The small page could be a Wiki quick guide that explains how to create a page, switch between different edit modes, or create a page, and more.|

Click *Attachment(s)* and *Revisions* links to open the *Attachments* details pane and the *Revisions* pane respectively right under the *Page information* bar. These two panes can be collapsed by clicking the relevant links again. |

h2. The page hierarchy in Wiki {anchor:id=KSuser.Wiki_Overview.Page_hierarchy}
*Wiki* is organized as a tree of pages in which each page may contain many sub-pages. The hierarchy is reflected on UI by the *Breadcrumb* and the page tree at the left pane. When a page is added, it is always defined as a sub-page to the current one. *Wiki* is a wiki platform which can host several wikis. So, you can have wikis for portals, wikis for groups or users. However, the page hierarchy is not reflected in the URLs as they are flatly accessible by their URLs.

h2. Wiki Spaces {anchor:id=KSuser.Wiki_Overview.Wiki_spaces}
Spaces represent a partitioning of *Wiki* data. A space is a set of pages. So, the space partitioning means they are independent trees. This separation is to enable *Wiki* to provide silos of knowledge for different interest groups.

There are 3 types of spaces:

* *Portal wiki*: wiki for the current portal.

* *Group wiki*: wiki available for members of a group.

* *User wiki*: wiki for personal pages.

{docbook}
<note>
    <para>
    In this document, Spaces are referred as wikis, particularly portal wikis, group wikis, and user wikis.
    </para>
    <para>
    Any space which has an implicit root page is named Wiki Home.
    </para>
</note>
{docbook}


h1. Work with Wiki pages {anchor:id=KSuser.Work_with_Wiki_pages}
Pages are sites where information in *Wiki* is stored and shared. Pages are stored within a *Space*. To do or view actions on a specific *Wiki* page, you should contact the administrator to get the appropriate permissions. See the [Page Permissions|#KSuser.Wiki_Administration.Page_permissions] for detailed permissions.

In a page, you can:

* [Create a page with its content using the simple markup language or the Rich Text editor|#KSuser.Work_with_Wiki_pages.Create_pages].

* [Edit a page|#KSuser.Work_with_Wiki_pages.Edit_pages].

* [Delete a page|#KSuser.Work_with_Wiki_pages.Delete_pages].

* [Move a page to another location|#KSuser.Work_with_Wiki_pages.Move_pages].

* [Watch a page|#KSuser.Work_with_Wiki_pages.Watch_pages].

* [View page information|#KSuser.Work_with_Wiki_pages.View_page_info].

h2. Create a page {anchor:id=KSuser.Work_with_Wiki_pages.Create_pages}
There are two ways to create a page:

*The first way* {anchor:id=KSuser.Work_with_Wiki_pages.Create_pages.First_way}

In this way, you need to use the toolbar.

*1.* Go to a Wiki space in which you want to create a page.

*2.* Click *Add Page* and select *Blank Page* or *From Template...* from the drop-down menu if you want to use an available template.

!images/add_wiki_page.png|align="center"!

If you select *From Template...*, a list of available templates appears.

!images/wiki_template.png|align="center"!

You can:

i. Click *Preview* corresponding to the template you want to see.

ii. Click *Select* corresponding to the template you want to select for your new page.

The template for your page is displayed.

 !images/wiki_available_template.png|align="center"!

*3.* Enter the title for your page. The page title must be unique.

*4.* Enter the content for your page by using *Wiki Markup* or the *Rich Text* editor.

*5.* Optionally, click *Preview* to see how your page looks like.

*6.* Click *Save* to finish.

*The second way* {anchor:id=KSuser.Work_with_Wiki_pages.Create_pages.Second_way}

In this way, you need to use the undefined link in a page.

In the *Wiki* application of eXo Platform, you can add a link pointing to a page which you are going to create later. Such links are called undefined links. These links are often used to remind other *Wiki* users to create the page.

*Add an undefined link for creating a page later*

*1.* Add a link by typing the page title between square brackets '{noformat}[[...]]{noformat}' or '{noformat}[.... ]{noformat}' (depending on your selected syntax) into your page body.

For example:

||Syntax||What you type|| What you get||
|Xwiki 2.0 |{noformat}[[eXo User Guide]]{noformat}|!images/undefined_link.png!|
|Confluence 1.0|{noformat}[eXo User Guide]{noformat}|!images/undefined_link.png!|

*2.* Click *Save* to save the page containing the link. The undefined link is colored in red with the underline.

*3.* Click the created red link to open the 'Add Page' form.

*4.* Follow the steps stated [above|#KSuser.Work_with_Wiki_pages.Create_pages.First_way] to enter the page title, content, and save the page.

h2. Edit a page {anchor:id=KSuser.Work_with_Wiki_pages.Edit_pages}
You can edit a page at any time provided that you have the edit permission on that page.

To edit a page, click *Edit* in the *Page Control* area. Your page will switch to the Edit mode.

!images/page_control.png|align="center"!

Now, you can rename the page and edit the page content. The toolbar in the edit mode will be changed to activate the following actions.

!images/wiki_page_edit.png|align="center"!

*Details:*
||Item|| Description||
|!images/no1.png!| Switch to the Rich Text (WYSIWYG) editor. |
|!images/no2.png!| Open the Wiki syntax help page. |
|!images/no3.png!| Display the preview mode of the currently edited content. Previewing a page helps you verify the result of rendering the markup you just entered without saving.|
|!images/no4.png!| Show more syntax help. |
|!images/no5.png!| Input the edit reason if neccessary.|
|!images/no6.png!| Save the current page and go back to the view mode.|
|!images/7.png!| Save the current page without sending notification to the watcher. |
|!images/8.png!| Discard the current changes and go back to the view mode. |


h2. Move a page to another location {anchor:id=KSuser.Work_with_Wiki_pages.Move_pages}

*1.* Select the page that you want to move.

*2.* Click *More* in the *Page Control* area, then select *Move Page* from the drop-down menu.

!images/wiki_move_page.png|align="center"!

The form to select the destination page appears.

!images/wiki_destination_page.png|align="center"!

*3.* Select the destination page.

*4.* Click *Move* to commit.

h2. Delete a page {anchor:id=KSuser.Work_with_Wiki_pages.Delete_pages}

*1.* Open the page you want to delete and select *More* in the *Page Control* area.

!images/Delete_page.png|align="center"!

*2.* Click *Delete Page* from the drop-down menu.

*3.* Click *OK* in the confirmation message to accept your deletion.

h2. View page information {anchor:id=KSuser.Work_with_Wiki_pages.View_page_info}

Viewing page information is accessible to users who have the View permission on that page. The page information provides you all details about related pages of the current page, the hierarchy structure of the current page, the page history, and more.

*1.* Select the page you want to view the information.

*2.* Click *More* from the page toolbar, then select *Page Info* from the drop-down menu.

All information of the opening page, including page summary, related pages, page hierarchy, recent changes, will be displayed.

!images/wiki_page_info.png|align="center"!


h3. Add a related page {anchor:id=KSuser.Work_with_Wiki_pages.Add_related_pages}
This feature allows you to add pages related to your page. This function is only activated to users with the Edit permission and can be done in the *Page Info* view.

*1.* Click *Add More Relations* in the [Page Info|#KSuser.Work_with_Wiki_pages.View_page_info] view, then select the related pages in the *Select a page* window.

*2.* Click *Select* to add the selected page to the list of the *Related Pages*.

!images/wiki_select_page.png|align="center"!

The related pages of the opening page are displayed in the side pane as below.

!images/wiki_related_page.png|align="center"!

h3. View a page history {anchor:id=KSuser.Work_with_Wiki_pages.View_page_history}

To access the page history, just click *View Page History* in the [Page Info|#KSuser.Work_with_Wiki_pages.View_page_info] view.

The *History Page* appears.

!images/page_history.png|align="center"!

h1. Work with attachments {anchor:id=KSuser.Work_with_attachment}
Attachments are any files enclosed with your pages. The attachments may be images, documents, presentation or multimedia files.

In this section, you will know how to:

* [View all the attachments of a page|#KSuser.Work_with_attachment.View_attachments].

* [Add an attachment|#KSuser.Work_with_attachment.Add_attachment].

* [Delete an attachment|#KSuser.Work_with_attachment.Delete_attachment].

* [Download an attachment|#KSuser.Work_with_attachment.Download_attachment].


h2. View all the attachments of a page {anchor:id=KSuser.Work_with_attachment.View_attachments}

*1.* Open the page you want to view its attachments.

*2.* Click *Attachment(s)* link from the *Page info* at the bottom right corner of the opening page.

!images/wiki_attachment.png|align="center"!


h2. Add an attachment to a page {anchor:id=KSuser.Work_with_attachment.Add_attachment}
There are two ways to add an attachment to a page:

*The first way* {anchor:id=Add_attachment_Attachment_pane}

In this way, you need to use the attachment pane at the bottom of the page.

*1.* Click the *Upload New File* field. The upload window will appear.

*2.* Select a file from your local device and click the *Open* button. The file will be uploaded automatically then.

*The second way* {anchor:id=Add_attachment_WYSIWYG editor}

In this way, you need to use the *WYSIWYG* editor (Rich Text editor).

*1.* Select a page to which you want to add an attachment.

*2.* Select *Edit* at the *Page Control* area. For more details, see the [Edit a page|#KSuser.Work_with_Wiki_pages.Edit_pages] section.

*3.* Select the *Rich Text* editor on the page toolbar.

!images/rich_text_editor.png|align="center"!

*4.* Click !images/Link_icon.png! on the toolbar of the *Rich Text* editor, then select *Attached File...* from the drop-down menu.

!images/wiki_attach_file.png|align="center"!

The *Link* form is displayed as below.

!images/wiki_link_form.png|align="center"!

*5.*  Select a file to upload by doing one of two following cases:

* *Upload a new file from your local device:*
*i.* Double-click *Upload new file* or click *Upload new file --> Select* in the *Current page* or *All pages* tab.

*ii.* Click *Browse* to select a file from your local device, then click *Upload*.

* *Select an existing file:* Double-click it or click it, then click *Select* in the *Current page* or *All pages* tab.

The form to edit the link parameters appears.

!images/wiki_edit_link.png|align="center"!

*6.* Edit the link parameters by typing the label and the tooltip for the link.

*7.* Click *Create Link* to commit.

The uploaded file will be in the undefined link format. By clicking this link, you can create a new page.


{docbook}
<note>
    <para>
    If you click <emphasis role="bold">Upload new file</emphasis> in the <emphasis role="bold">All pages</emphasis> tab, it means that the attachment is added to all pages.
    </para>
</note>
{docbook}

h2. Delete an attachment {anchor:id=KSuser.Work_with_attachment.Delete_attachment}
To delete an attachment, just click !images/Delete_icon.png! corresponding to the attachment.


h2. Download an attachment {anchor:id=KSuser.Work_with_attachment.Download_attachment}

To download an attachment, just click the name of the attached file.

h2. Link to an inserted image {anchor:id=KSuser.Work_with_attachment.Link_to_image}

*1.* Click !images/Image_btn.png! on the text editor, then click *Insert Image...*

!images/wiki_link_to_image.png|align="center"!

*2.* Select an inserted image of the current page or click the *All Pages* tab to select an image attached to another page in the space.

*3.* Click *Insert Image*.

h1. Use the WYSIWYG Editor {anchor:id=KSuser.Wiki.Use_WYSIWYG_editor}

*WYSIWYG* stands for What You See Is What You Get. You can switch between the *Source* and *WYSIWYG* editors at any time by clicking !images/rich_text_editor.png! or !images/source_editor_btn.png!. In the *Source* editor, which is selected by default when you edit a page, you have to use the wiki markup language for text formatting, while the *WYSIWYG* editor enables the contents to be appeared during editing that is very similar to the published result. Thanks to available tools on this editor, you can format your content visually without using *Wiki* markups.

!images/wiki_wysiwyg_editor.png|align="center"!


{docbook}
<note>
    <para>
    If the final result is not similar to what you wish when editing a page by the <emphasis role="bold">WYSIWYG</emphasis> editor, you can go back to the <emphasis role="bold">Source</emphasis> editor and use <emphasis role="bold">Wiki</emphasis> markups to edit the content.
    </para>
</note>
{docbook}

To learn how to use the *WYSIWYG* editor, you can refer to these guides.

* [Admin guide|http://platform.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/AdminGuide/WysiwygEditor]
* [User guide|http://platform.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/Features/WysiwygEditor]

h1. Syntax Help {anchor:id=KSuser.Wiki.Syntax_Help}
If you do not know how to use a syntax, you can use the Syntax Help function. The *Syntax Help* is displayed by clicking !images/Wiki_help_btn.png! from the page toolbar. When being clicked, a lateral pane slides beside the editing area will show all the information of the most common syntaxes.
The lateral pane can be hidden by clicking !images/Close_button.png! in the upper right corner or by clicking !images/Wiki_help_btn.png! again.

You can click !images/More_syntaxes.png! at the bottom of short *Help Tips* form to view the full help.

h1. Work with Macros {anchor:id=KSuser.Wiki.Work_with_Macros}
Using a macro, you can apply extra formatting, functionality and customization to your content.
You can easily add macro tags by using the *Rich Text* editor.

*1.* Click *Rich Text* to open the rich text editor.

*2.* Click *Macros*, then select *Insert Macros...* from the drop-down menu.

!images/wiki_macros.png|align="center"!

The *Insert Macros* form appears.

!images/wiki_macros_form.png|align="center"!

The macros are classified into different categories: *Content*, *Formatting*, *Navigation*.

*3.* Select a macro category.

*4.* Select your desired macro from the selected categories list and then click the *Select* button; or double-click it. For example, if you select the *Box* macro, you are redirected to the Macro Parameters form.

!images/Macro_parameters_form.png|align="center"!

*5.* Enter parameters into the corresponding fields for your selected macro. Click *Insert Macro* to perform your macro insertion; Or, click *Previous* to return to initial *Insert Macro* form.

The following table describes specific functions of common macros.

||Macro||Function||
|*Excerpt*| Create additional information for the current page and it can be set to "hidden" in the current page, but displayed to add more information as the summary about the page when it is used with the Page Tree macro.|
|*Include Page*| Include the content of another page in the current page.|
|*Box* | Draw a box around the provided content.|
|*Color*| Change the text color. {example}{example} !images/wiki_macro_color.png|align="center"! |
|*Code*| Highlight code snippets of various programming languages.  {example}{example} !images/wiki_macro_code.png|align="center"!|
|*Error Message*|Display an error message note.|
|*Float* |Allow a content to 'float' on the left or the right. {example}{example} !images/wiki_macro_float.png|align="center"!|
|*Info Message* |Display an info message. !images/wiki_macro_info_message.png|align="center"! |
|*NoFormat* |Keep the content displayed when you type. !images/wiki_macro_noFormat.png|align="center"!|
|*Note Message*|Display a note message. !images/wiki_macro_note.png|align="center"!|
|*Panel* |Embrace a block of text within a fully customizable panel. !images/wiki_macro_panel.png|align="center"!|
|*Table* {example}{example}*Table cell*{example}{example}*Table row*| Inset a table. {example}{example}Insert a table cell. {example}{example}Insert a table row.|
|*Tip Message* |Display a tip message block.{example}{example} !images/wiki_macro_tip.png|align="center"! |
|*Warning Message* |Display a warning message block. {example}{example} !images/wiki_macro_warning.png|align="center"!|
|*Anchor* |Create an anchor for the selected contents. |
|*Children* |Display the children and descendants of a specific page in the current page. {example}{example} !images/wiki_macro_children.png|align="center"!  |
|*Page Tree* |Display the hierarchy of a page in the current page. {example}{example} !images/wiki_macro_page_tree.png|align="center"!|
|*Related Pages* |Render the related pages of the current page. |
|*Table of Content* |Generate a table of content for the current page. |
|*Section* & *Column* |Using the Section and Column macros allows you to write the content in the columns in the section. {example}{example}!images/wiki_macro_section_column.png|align="center"! |

h1. Work with page versions {anchor:id=KSuser.Wiki.Work_with_Page_versions}
When editing the content of a page, *Wiki* will automatically create a version of that page after it is saved. Thanks to the page versions, you can make changes to the page safely and rollback to an earlier version without worrying about messing things up.

In the [Page History|#KSuser.Work_with_Wiki_pages.View_page_history] view, you can see all versions of a page.

Each version includes the following information:

* Revision numbers.

* Author making changes.

* Date and time when changes are made.

* Summary (if any).

In the Page History page, you can:

* [View versions of a page|#KSuser.Work_with_page_version.View_versions].

* [Compare page versions|#KSuser.Work_with_page_version.Compare_versions].

* [Restore a page version to the current version|#KSuser.Work_with_page_version.Restore_page_version].

{docbook}
<note>
    <para>
    All functions, including viewing, comparing and restoring, can also be done by clicking the <emphasis role="bold">Revisions</emphasis> link at the <emphasis role="bold">Page Info</emphasis> bar. One pop-up pane appears right under this bar, allowing you to do the same steps as described below.
    </para>
</note>
{docbook}

h2. View versions of a page {anchor:id=KSuser.Work_with_page_version.View_versions}
To view a specific version of a page, just click a version number in the *Page History* page. The selected version of that page will be displayed.

!images/wiki_view_version.png|align="center"!

At a version of the page, you can do the following actions:

||Item|| Description||
|!images/no1.png!|Compare the current version with the selected one.|
|!images/no2.png!|Replace the current version with the selected version.|
|!images/no3.png!|Go to the *Page History* page.|
| *Prev* |View content of the previous version.|
| *Next* |View content of the next version.|

h2. Compare page versions {anchor:id=KSuser.Work_with_page_version.Compare_versions}

*Wiki* tracks histories of changes to pages by maintaining a version of the page each time it is modified. To compare two versions, select two checkboxes corresponding to each relevant version, then click !images/Compare_selected_button.png!.

!images/Select_page_version.png|align="center"!

A page which shows the changes between these two versions will be displayed.

!images/wiki_compare_version1.png|align="center"!

The changes between two versions will be marked with colors:

*  Words/lines which are red-highlighted with strike-throughs indicate that they were removed.

*  Words/lines highlighted in green indicate that they were added.


{docbook}
<note>
    <para>
    Only two revisions can be selected at one time.
    </para>
</note>
{docbook}

h2. Restore a page version to the current version  {anchor:id=KSuser.Work_with_page_version.Restore_page_version}
When you notice that there are changes in the current page version that you are not satisfied, you can rollback to an older version of that page quickly.

To restore an older version, click !images/Restore_button.png! corresponding to your desired version in the *Page History* page.


{docbook}
<note>
    <para>
    Restoring an older version will create a copy of that version. For example, if the [current version (v.15)] is restored to the [older version (v.10)], <emphasis role="bold">Wiki</emphasis> will create a new version (v.16) containing contents of v.10. The version v.16 will become the current version.
    </para>
</note>
{docbook}

h1. Work with Spaces {anchor:id=KSuser.Wiki.Work_with_Spaces}
*Wiki* provides permanent bookmarkable URLs to all wiki pages. *Wiki* will resolve wiki pages by inspecting the URL used to call it and outputting links as clean URLs in the following form:

{code}http://hostname/$CONTAINER/$SITE/$NAV_URI/[$OWNER_TYPE/$OWNER]/$WIKI_PAGE_URI{code}

|| Item|| Description||
|*$CONTAINER$*|The portal container.|
|*$SITE*|The portal site (e.g,'classic').|
|*{noformat}$NAV_URI{noformat}* |The URI of navigation bound to a page containing the *Wiki* portlet.|
|*{noformat}$OWNER_TYPE{noformat}*| May be 'group' or 'user'.|
|*$OWNER* |The wiki owner which can be name of user or of group.|
|*{noformat}$WIKI_PAGE_URI{noformat}* |The URI inferred automatically from the wiki page name.|

Any wiki page should be accessed by a friendly URL, for example:

* Portal wiki URL: http://hostname/portal/classic/*wiki/eXo+Wiki+Specification.

* Group wiki URL: http://hostname/portal/classic/*wiki/group/platform/Administrators/Admin+Guide.

* Personal wiki page URL: http://hostname/portal/classic/*wiki/user/john/Sandbox.


h1. Search {anchor:id=KSuser.Wiki.Search}
In *Wiki*, you can search spaces, or pages in a space and attached files. There are two types of search in *Wiki*:

* [Quick Search|#KSuser.Wiki.Search.Quick_search]
* [Advanced Search|#KSuser.Wiki.Advanced_Search]

h2. Quick Search {anchor:id=KSuser.Wiki.Search.Quick_search}

*1.* Enter a key word in the search box.

!images/wiki_quick_search.png|align="center"!

*2.* Select your desired page or space from the drop-down menu. You will be redirected to the selected page or space.

h2. Advanced Search {anchor:id=KSuser.Wiki.Advanced_Search}
The Advanced Search function allows you to search with a key word in a specific space. This mode helps you limit the search results.

*1.* Enter a key term into the search box and hit the *Enter* key.

If the results are matched with the key word, the search results are displayed like the illustration below.

!images/wiki_advanced_search_result.png|align="center"!

If no results matched with the key words, the search screen informs "*there is no search result...!*"

*2.* Click !images/down_arrow_icon.png! to select a space from the drop-down menu to define a scale where to search for the entered word.

*3.* Click *Search*.

h1. Wiki Administration {anchor:id=KSuser.Wiki.Wiki_Administration}


{docbook}
<note>
    <para>
    This section is for administrators only.
    </para>
</note>
{docbook}

The administrator has the highest right in *Wiki*. The administrator can delete a page, change the space settings, set the edit permission for users, and more.

h2. Set up space settings {anchor:id=KSuser.Wiki_Administration.Set_up_space_settings}

For each space, you can manage page templates and change the syntax used.

{docbook}
<citetitle>
<para>
    <emphasis role="bold">Access the Space Settings page</emphasis>
</para>
</citetitle>
{docbook}
*1.* Open a *Wiki* space.

*2.* Click *Browse*, then select *Space Settings*.

!images/wiki_space_settings.png|align="center"!

The *Space Settings* page appear.

!images/wiki_space_settings_page.png|align="center"!

Now you can:

* [Manage permissions on spaces and pages|#KSuser.Wiki_Administration.Manage_permissions].
* [Manage a page template|#KSuser.Wiki_Administration.Manage_page_tempplate].
* [Set up wiki syntax|#KSuser.Wiki_Administration.Set_up_syntax].

h2. Manage Permissions {anchor:id=KSuser.Wiki_Administration.Manage_permissions}
*Wiki* gives you the choice to make a space or an individual page to be open or restricted to specific users, groups or memberships.
There are two levels of permissions in *Wiki*: Space Permissions and Page Permissions.

h3. Space Permissions  {anchor:id=KSuser.Wiki_Administration.Manage_permissions.Space_Permission}
Each space may have its own permissions. Space permissions determine which actions a user can do within the space. A permission can be assigned to any users, groups or memberships.

To change the space permission, open a space, click *Browse* and select *Space Settings* from the drop-down list.
Clik *Permission* in the *Space Settings* page that appears.

!images/wiki_space_permissions_page.png|align="center"!

There are some permissions to a space as follows:
|| Permission|| Description||
|*View Pages*|Specify who can view and watch pages of this space, its attachments and history.|
|*Edit Pages*|Specify who can edit pages of this space.|
|*Admin Pages*|Specify who have the administration rights on this space.|
|*Admin Space*|Specify who can administrate the space permissions and settings|

In the *Space Permissions* form, you can add or remove the space permissions of the users, groups and memberships.

h4. Add space permissions {anchor:id=KSuser.Wiki_Administration.Add_space_permissions}
In the *Space Permissions* form, you can add permissions for individual users, groups of users or memberships.

*1.* Click !images/select_permission_icon.png! to assign permissions to a user, a group or a membership respectively.

The form to select the user, the group and the membership appears.

*2.* Select a user, a group or a membership, then click  *Add*.

*3.* Click the plus icon to add the selectors to the *Owner* tab in the *Space Permissions* form.

*4.* Click the checkboxes corresponding to each permission you want to assign to the selectors.

*5.* Click *Save* to commit.


{docbook}
<note>
    <para>
    View, Edit, Admin Pages permissions are applied by default to any pages of the space unless specific page permissions are set. The super user has all permissions implicitly.
    </para>
</note>
{docbook}

h4. Delete space permissions {anchor:id=KSuser.Wiki_Administration.Delete_space_permissions}

To delete the permissions of a user, group or a membership in a space, just click !images/Remove_icon.png! corresponding to a user/a group or a membership in the *Space Permissions* form.

h3. Page Permissions {anchor:id=KSuser.Wiki_Administration.Page_permissions}
The *Page Permissions* allows you to set the view and edit permissions for a specific page of a space.

*1.* Open a page of the space that you want to set the permissions.

*2.* Click *More* and select *Page Permissions* from the drop-down menu.

!images/wiki_page_permissions.png|align="center"!

The *Page Permissions* form appears.

!images/wiki_page_permissions_form.png|align="center"!

Pages are viewable/editable according to the space permission. On each page, a user with the *Admin Pages* permission will be able to override the view and edit permissions on this specific page.

A *Page Permissions* action appears in the page action menu when the user has the *Admin Pages* permission.

You can add and delete the *View Pages Permission* or the *Edit Pages Permissions* for the page. Do the same as *[Add space permissions|#KSuser.Wiki_Administration.Add_space_permissions]* and *[Delete space permissions|#KSuser.Wiki_Administration.Delete_space_permissions]*.


h3. Manage a page template {anchor:id=KSuser.Wiki_Administration.Manage_page_tempplate}

When adding a new page, you are not required to write the content from scratch. You can start by selecting a page template which is actually a *Wiki* page with predefined contents.

In the *Space Settings* form, select the *Template* tab, and the form to manage templates appears.

!images/wiki_setting_template.png|align="center"!

*Details:*
||Item ||Description ||
|!images/no1.png!|[Search for a template|#KSuser.Wiki_Administration.Search_templates].|
|!images/no2.png!|[Create a new template|#KSuser.Wiki_Administration.Add_templates].|
|!images/no3.png!|[Edit a template|#KSuser.Wiki_Administration.Edit_templates].|
|!images/no4.png!|[Delete a template|#KSuser.Wiki_Administration.Delete_templates].|

h4. Search for a template {anchor:id=KSuser.Wiki_Administration.Search_templates}

This feature allows you to find your desired template quickly from the existing list as follows:

*1.* Input a word included in the title of your desired template in the *Search* textbox.

*2.* Press the *Enter* key; Or click the *Search* button next to the textbox to start your search.

All matching results which contain your entered search term are displayed right below the textbox.


{docbook}
<note>
    <para>
    The <emphasis role="bold">Search</emphasis> function is only performed by the template titles, and you must enter a complete word into the <emphasis role="bold">Search</emphasis> textbox. For example, to find the template whose title contains "daily report", you can input "report" rather than "repo", or "daily" rather "ly".

    </para>
</note>
{docbook}

h4. Create a new template {anchor:id=KSuser.Wiki_Administration.Add_templates}

*1.* Click *Add more...* and the sample template form appears.

!images/wiki_sample_template.png|align="center"!

*2.* Add the title for the template.

*3.* Write the description in the *Description...*.

*4.* Write the content for the template.

*5.* Select the *Syntax* to write the content.

*6.* Click *Save Template* at the *Page Control* area. A message will inform your successful template creation.

h4. Edit a template {anchor:id=KSuser.Wiki_Administration.Edit_templates}

*1.* Click the *Edit* icon corresponding to the template you want to edit.

*2.* Change the title, the description, the content as you want.

*3.* Click *Save Template* at the *Page Control* area.

h4.  Delete a template {anchor:id=KSuser.Wiki_Administration.Delete_templates}

*1.* Click !images/Delete_icon.png! corresponding to the template you want to delete.

*2.* Click *OK* in the pop-up confirmation message.


h3. Set up the wiki syntax {anchor:id=KSuser.Wiki_Administration.Set_up_syntax}

By setting up the Wiki syntax, you can select the default syntax or use another one while writing a document.

*1.* Click *Syntax* in the *Space Settings* page.

 !images/wiki_setting_syntax.png|align="center"!

*2.* Click the *Default Syntax* box and select a syntax from the drop-down menu. This syntax is set as the default for your document.

In case you want to use another syntax, tick the "*Allow user to select other syntaxes*" checkbox.


{docbook}
<note>
<para>It is highly recommended that you should use such simple xyntaxes, such as XWiki 2.0, or Confluence 1.0. </para>
</note>
{docbook}
